context: Act 1 Chapter 1.1 — Diesel approaches at The Pit and issues his follow/test challenge

lines.text: The Pit is winding down. Cars pulling out, engines cooling, money changing hands in the shadows. You're leaning against the CRX, replaying every turn in your head, when the hairs on the back of your neck stand up.
A shadow detaches from a concrete pillar thirty feet away. It moves toward you with the slow, deliberate certainty of a man who has never rushed anything in his life.

He's tall. Lean in a way that suggests wire cable, not absence. Late forties, maybe older — hard to tell. His face is carved from the same concrete as the pillars around him. He studies you the way a mechanic studies an engine — looking for the fault lines.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: You're sloppy.
No introduction. No preamble. Just a verdict.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Your corner entry is aggressive but your exits are weak. You brake too late and then you're fighting the car through the apex instead of letting it rotate. You carry speed in but you don't carry it out. That's backward.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Your throttle application is binary. On or off. No modulation. That CRX is front-wheel drive — you need to trail the throttle through transitions or you'll understeer into a wall.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: And your line through the chicane was a full car-width off. You gave away a half-second every lap.

lines.label: diesel_responds_who
lines.text: He doesn't answer immediately. He looks at your car. Looks at your tires. Looks at you.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Someone who's been where you are. A long time ago.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: The question isn't who I am. The question is whether you're worth the conversation.

lines.label: diesel_responds_teach
lines.text: Something shifts in his expression. Not a smile — Diesel doesn't smile. But the hard line of his mouth softens by a fraction. Like a locked door moving a millimeter.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Hmm.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Most kids your age would have told me to go to hell. Or tried to prove me wrong with words instead of driving.

lines.label: diesel_responds_won
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: You won a race against drivers who were worse than you. Congratulations. You're the tallest person in a room full of people sitting down.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Winning doesn't mean you're good. It means you were good enough tonight. Against this field. In these conditions. Change any of those variables and you're sideways into a barrier.
The words sting. They sting because they're true.

lines.label: diesel_test_offer
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: I want to see something. There's an industrial strip on the east side — old factory road. Two miles of broken asphalt, off-camber turns, and blind crests.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Simple rules. You follow me. Full speed. I set the pace, you match it. I don't care if you're faster — I care if you can read the road.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: The surface changes three times. Asphalt to concrete to gravel and back. If you don't adjust, you spin. If you panic, you crash. If you overthink, you fall behind.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Tomorrow night. 1 AM. Be there or don't.
He turns. Walks toward the darkness. Then stops.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: One more thing. This isn't a race. If you try to pass me, we're done. You follow. You learn. Or you go home.
He disappears into the industrial dark. You never heard a car start. You never saw headlights. It's like the night just swallowed him whole.
--- The next night. 1 AM. The industrial strip. ---

The factory road stretches ahead under a sky the color of bruised plums. No streetlights. No markings. Just the matte black coupe idling at the far end, headlights cutting through the dark like a predator's eyes.
You pull up behind Diesel. He doesn't acknowledge you. The coupe's brake lights flicker once — a signal. Then he's moving.

lines.label: test_radio_start
lines.speaker: Diesel (Radio)
lines.text: First corner. Late apex. The surface breaks up on exit — keep your inputs smooth or the rear will step out.
His voice on the radio is calm. Measured. Like he's reading the weather.

lines.speaker: Diesel (Radio)
lines.text: Concrete section. Less grip. Brake earlier than you think you need to. Your instinct will be wrong.

lines.speaker: Diesel (Radio)
lines.text: Good. Now — feel the gravel transition. Don't fight the car. Let the rear slide. Steer with the throttle, not the wheel.

The coupe ahead of you flows through the broken road like water. Every movement minimal. Every correction invisible. This is driving stripped to its essence — no crowd, no money, no ego. Just machine and surface and the dark.

lines.speaker: Diesel (Radio)
lines.text: Blind crest ahead. Commit. If you lift off now, the weight transfers forward and you'll overshoot the next turn. Trust the road. Trust the car.

lines.speaker: Diesel (Radio)
lines.text: Commitment isn't about being fearless. It's about knowing exactly how much risk the moment demands and giving exactly that. No more. No less.
The industrial strip spits you out onto a gravel apron overlooking the harbor. Diesel's coupe is already there. Parked. Engine off. Like he's been waiting for hours.

lines.label: post_test_kept_pace
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: You kept pace.
He says it like a fact. No praise. No enthusiasm. But you're learning that from Diesel, a fact is the highest form of compliment.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Your surface transitions are still rough. You hesitate at the grip change instead of flowing through it. But you didn't panic. And you didn't try to show off.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: That's something I can work with.

lines.label: post_test_fell_behind
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: You fell behind.
A statement. Not a judgment. He could be telling you the time.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: The gravel section broke you. You lifted off and the gap opened up. Once you were chasing, you started overdriving to catch up, which made it worse.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: But you didn't quit. You didn't spin. And you made it to the end. That's more than most.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: It's not enough yet. But it could be.

lines.label: post_test_end
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: The underground here — it's not what it used to be. It's gotten faster. More money. More stupid. People race for clout now, not because they love driving.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: You need a foundation. Or this city will eat you whole and spit out someone you don't recognize.
He pauses. Stares at the harbor lights.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: I'll be in touch.
The matte black coupe slips away into the night. No fanfare. No taillights. Just gone.
